title: Words in Context
subtitle: Mastering Vocabulary Through Context
learning_objectives: The Core: Master choosing precise words based on context clues
The Skill: Match both meaning AND tone/register
The Problem: Multiple words may mean 'correct'—choose the most PRECISE fit
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase SELECT Strategy for 100% provable word choices

content.heading: The Main Quest
bullet_points: Decode context clues for precise word choice
Choose the MOST precise word, not just any correct word

core_principle.title: Context is King
core_principle.description: SAT words-in-context questions test your ability to choose words based on HOW they're used in specific passages. Context always trumps memorized definitions.

strategy_steps.title: Cover the Target Word
strategy_steps.description: Physically or mentally remove the word and read without it
strategy_steps.why: Forces you to use context instead of being influenced by what's there

example.original: The scientist's initial hypothesis proved to be completely [erroneous].
example.covered: The scientist's initial hypothesis proved to be completely _______.
example.read_without: Focus on what the blank needs, not what was there

strategy_steps.title: Read Surrounding Sentences
strategy_steps.description: Look before and after for context clues

example.text: The scientist's initial hypothesis proved to be completely _______. After months of rigorous testing, the data contradicted every one of her predictions.
example.key_clues: 'data contradicted every one of her predictions' = hypothesis was wrong

strategy_steps.title: Predict a Simple Word
strategy_steps.description: What everyday word would fit here?
strategy_steps.why_matters: Your prediction guides you to the right category of meaning
strategy_steps.note: Don't worry if your prediction isn't fancy—focus on the concept

worked_example.passage: Despite its ________ appearance, the abandoned mansion held a strange fascination for local residents. Children would dare each other to approach its weathered gates.
step_by_step: Step 1: Cover word, read: 'Despite its ____ appearance...'
Step 2: Clues: 'abandoned,' 'dare each other to approach,' 'weathered' → looks scary/uninviting
Step 4: 'Despite' signals contrast → looks scary BUT holds fascination

context_clue_types.definition: Passage directly explains or restates the word's meaning

example.sentence: The archaeologist's discovery was unprecedented—no similar artifacts had been found in over fifty years.
example.clue: 'no similar artifacts...in fifty years' defines unprecedented

context_clue_types.definition: Passage gives examples of the concept

example.sentence: The manager's explanation was ________: she outlined all the procedures, clarified each step, and answered every question.
example.clues: Examples of being clear: outlined, clarified, answered

context_clue_types.definition: Passage shows what the word is NOT

example.sentence: Despite its forbidding appearance, the mansion held fascination.
example.clue: 'Despite' signals contrast—looks forbidding BUT creates fascination

context_clue_types.definition: Passage shows results of the word's action or meaning

example.sentence: The data was ________; as a result, the team had to revise all their conclusions.
example.clue: Effect: had to revise conclusions → Cause: data was wrong/contradictory

example.sentence: The student's ________ approach to studying impressed even the most demanding professors.
example.clue: Positive tone ('impressed'), formal context (professors) → needs positive, academic word
example.word_meaning: rigorous, meticulous, systematic (NOT cool or awesome)

clue_hierarchy.title: Which Clues Are Strongest?
ranking: 5. General Tone (least specific but still useful)
clue_hierarchy.strategy: Use multiple clue types together for strongest answer

elements.reveal: Context clues are more reliable than memorized definitions. Even if you know a word's definition, ALWAYS check that it fits the specific context.

content.heading: PHASE 3: Evaluate for PRECISION
content.subtitle: Choose the MOST Precise Fit, Not Just Any Correct Word

core_principle.title: Precision Beats Correctness
core_principle.description: On the SAT, multiple words may be technically correct. The right answer is the one that BEST matches both meaning AND tone/register.

evaluation_criteria.question: Does this word capture the specific meaning needed?

levels.description: General meaning right but not most specific

evaluation_criteria.question: Does this word match the passage's formality level?

formal_passage.example: Formal: 'The data demonstrates conclusive evidence' NOT 'The data shows proof'

informal_passage.example: Informal: 'She helped me figure it out' NOT 'She facilitated my comprehension'

evaluation_criteria.question: Does the word's strength match the context?
Does the word's emotional association fit?

common_traps.description: Choosing word based on what you learned, not what fits
common_traps.example: 'Novel' means 'new' BUT in 'She published her first novel,' it means 'book'
common_traps.fix: Always check context, ignore memorized definitions

common_traps.description: Picking first word that works instead of BEST word
common_traps.example: Both 'unusual' and 'unprecedented' mean 'rare,' but which is MORE precise?
common_traps.fix: Test all options, choose most specific

common_traps.description: Choosing word with right meaning but wrong formality

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the SELECT Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Cross Out → Look for Clues → Evaluate Precision
content.passage: Despite its ________ appearance, the abandoned mansion held a strange fascination for local residents. Children would dare each other to approach its weathered gates, and even adults found themselves stealing glances at its crumbling facade during evening walks.
content.question: Which word best completes the passage?
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: Cover and predict. Phase 2: Find contrast clue ('Despite'). Phase 3: Check meaning, tone, and precision.

content.explanation:
Let's apply the 3 phases:

PHASE 1—Predict: 'scary,' 'unwelcoming,' 'threatening'

PHASE 2—Context clues:
- CONTRAST clue: 'Despite' signals opposite relationship
- 'abandoned,' 'weathered,' 'crumbling' = looks uninviting
- 'dare each other to approach' = scary/challenging
- 'Despite' = looks X BUT creates fascination (X = something negative)

PHASE 3—Evaluate precision:

A: 'beautiful' ✗ WRONG MEANING—'Despite' wouldn't make sense (beautiful appearance wouldn't contrast with fascination)

B: 'forbidding' ✓ CORRECT
- MEANING: 'forbidding' = threatening/unwelcoming (matches 'dare each other')
- TONE: Formal, appropriate for narrative description
- PRECISION: Captures exact quality that makes children dare each other
- CONTRAST: 'Despite forbidding appearance...fascination' = perfect opposition

C: 'enormous' ✗ WRONG FOCUS—Size doesn't explain why children 'dare' or why 'despite' is needed

D: 'expensive' ✗ IRRELEVANT—Cost has nothing to do with the context clues about appearance

content.heading: Master These Patterns—Perfect Word Choice Every Time

rows: or, that is, means, refers to
such as, for example, like, including
'data was wrong; therefore had to revise'

content.expert_insight: Most precise word wins. Even if multiple words are technically correct, choose the one that best matches BOTH meaning AND tone for that specific context.

content.heading: Words in Context Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Cross out target word, read without it, predict simple word that fits
Phase 2: Look for context clues—definition, example, contrast, cause-effect, or tone
Phase 3: Evaluate for precision—choose most specific word matching both meaning AND tone
The 100% Rule: Context clues trump memorized definitions; most precise word wins over any correct word
content.strategy_reminder: Remember SELECT: Study context, Eliminate target word, Look for clues, Evaluate each option, Choose most precise, Test against context
content.expert_insight: Common traps: (1) Using memorized definitions instead of context, (2) Picking first correct answer instead of BEST, (3) Ignoring tone/formality level.

slides.title: Mastery Check
slides.question:
The archaeologist's discovery was truly ________; no similar artifacts had been found in over fifty years of excavations at the site. The find would require completely revising existing theories about the civilization.

Which word best fits the blank?
slides.explanation:
Phase analysis:

PHASE 1—Predict: 'rare,' 'never-before,' 'unique'

PHASE 2—Context clues:
DEFINITION CLUE: 'no similar artifacts in over fifty years' directly defines the word
Also: 'require completely revising theories' = extremely significant/unusual

PHASE 3—Precision evaluation:

A: 'significant' ✗ PARTIALLY CORRECT but too vague—doesn't capture the 'never before seen' aspect that 'no similar artifacts in fifty years' emphasizes

B: 'unprecedented' ✓ MOST PRECISE
- MEANING: 'unprecedented' literally = 'never done before,' perfectly matches 'no similar artifacts in fifty years'
- TONE: Formal, academic—fits archaeological context
- INTENSITY: Strong enough to match 'revising existing theories'
- SPECIFICITY: Most precise capture of the uniqueness

C: 'valuable' ✗ WRONG FOCUS—While discovery is valuable, the context clue emphasizes rarity/uniqueness, not worth

D: 'interesting' ✗ TOO WEAK—Understates significance; wrong tone (too casual for formal archaeological writing)

strategy_card.title: The SELECT Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Example: for example, such as, like
Cause-Effect: because, therefore, as a result
Tone: formal vs. informal, positive vs. negative
Choose MOST precise, not just any correct

strategy_card.the_100_rule: Context clues beat memorized definitions. Most precise word wins over any technically correct word.

common_mistakes: Relying on memorized definitions instead of context
Picking first correct answer instead of BEST answer
Ignoring tone and formality level of passage
Missing subtle context clues in surrounding sentences
